process.name: OAS enquiry – triage and knowledge support
process.description: High-level view of how a citizen enquiry about Old Age Security (OAS) flows across channels, call centre, EVA, and program systems. This is a simplified demo, not an official process map.
process.scenario: Citizen calls Service Canada to ask about OAS eligibility and next steps.

steps.label: Dials Service Canada OAS number
steps.notes: Entry point into the service journey.

steps.label: Explains situation to the agent and asks questions
steps.notes: Free-form explanation; key facts captured by the agent.

steps.label: Receives explanation and next steps
steps.notes: Guidance informed by EVA-assisted knowledge and rules (demo).

steps.label: Presents OAS / benefits menu
steps.notes: Static IVR tree in this demo.

steps.label: Routes call to OAS agent queue
steps.notes: Future EVA integration could improve routing.

steps.label: Greets caller and opens client profile
Summarizes client situation in EVA prompt
steps.notes: Agent uses EVA DA / EVA Chat to capture the scenario.

steps.label: Explains eligibility result and next steps
steps.notes: Agent uses EVA answer as a base, then adapts in their own words.

steps.label: Retrieves OAS policies and job aids (RAG)
steps.notes: EVA DA pulls from curated OAS content (demo).

steps.label: Applies simplified eligibility rules (RaC-style)
steps.notes: Static demo rule check: age, residency, contributions.

steps.label: Receives updated claim or application (future step)
steps.notes: Out of scope for this demo.

highlights: Shows how EVA sits between call centre agents and curated knowledge / rules.
Demonstrates a citizen-to-system journey without exposing real client data.
Provides a starting point for more detailed BPMN / swimlane models.
opportunities: Automate capture of client situations as structured prompts.
Integrate with IVR for better routing and early advice.
Connect to downstream program systems for end-to-end visibility.
summary.disclaimer: Static demo only – this is not an official OAS process and must not be treated as authoritative.
